Hello Colin,

We use RMSprop in my lab, but I must admit I have not taken t=
he time to figure out what makes it work so well. I=E2=80=99d love to hear =
your summary!


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor, Computer Sci=
ence
Director, Evolving Artificial Intelligence Lab <http://evolvingai.org/=
>
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

> On May 6, 2015,=
 at 3:23 PM, Colin Green colin.green1@... [neat] <neat@...=
m> wrote:
> 
> 
> Hi Ken,
> 
> Nice work, I like it. It's very clear and ni=
cely organised.
> 
> And yes I'm still lurking! Recently I've been thinking=
 about different types of model (as opposed to the standard 'node with sigm=
oid' model), improvements in gradient descent such as RMSProp, and whether =
there's merit in running GD on a network but with an evolved weight learnin=
g rule.
> 
> RMSProp is worth looking into if people haven't encountered it=
. I was quite surprised that such a simple improvement hadn't emerged earli=
er (willing to summarise if folks are interested).
> 
> Colin
> 
> _,_
> 
>=
 


--Apple-Mail=_845C2826-4D64-4F9A-858A-8A3EE78CFBEA
